If $f:\mathbb{N}\to \{-1,+1\}$ then is it true that for every $C>0$ there exist $d,m\geq 1$ such that\[\left\lvert \sum_{1\leq k\leq m}f(kd)\right\rvert > C?\]



The Erd\H{o}s discrepancy problem. This is true, and was proved by Tao \cite{Ta16}, who also proved the more general case when $f$ takes values on the unit sphere.

In several places (e.g. \cite{Er64b}, \cite{Er65b}, and \cite{Er81}) Erd\H{o}s further conjectured that\[\max_{md\leq x}\left\lvert \sum_{1\leq k\leq m}f(kd)\right\rvert \gg \log x.\]In \cite{Er85c} Erd\H{o}s also asks about the special case when $f$ is multiplicative.




References


[Er64b] Erd\H{o}s, P., Problems and results on diophantine approximations. Compositio Math. (1964), 52-65.

[Er65b] Erd\H{o}s, Paul, Some recent advances and current problems in number theory. Lectures on Modern Mathematics, Vol. III (1965), 196-244.

[Er81] Erd\H{o}s, P., On the combinatorial problems which I would most like to see solved. Combinatorica (1981), 25-42.

[Er85c] Erd\H{o}s, P., On some of my problems in number theory I would most like to see solved. Number theory (Ootacamund, 1984) (1985), 74-84.

[Ta16] Tao, Terence, The Erd\H{o}s discrepancy problem. Discrete Anal. (2016), Paper No. 1, 29.
